title: labour-council-leader-i-want-our-school-meals-to-be-nitrite-free
story: A Herald on Sunday investigation recently found that three-quarters of Scotlandrsquos councils have school menus that include processed meats which contain nitrites. That is only possible because the nutritional standards set by the Scottish Government allows it. Thatrsquos why, when presented with the newspapers findings, local government body Cosla responded that councils ldquoadhere closely to national nutritional standards.In the coming weeks Scotlandrsquos schools will break for summer. When childrenin August nitrites should be disappearing off the school menus across the country.Herald on Sunday campaign: time to dump "nitro" meat from schools and hospitalsThis doesnrsquot require legislative change. Nicola Sturgeon and her Deputy John Swinney should get their skates on, adjust the national nutritional standards and ban cancer-linked chemicals from Scotlandrsquos school canteens. Should they do so they will have the full support of the Scottish Labour Party.CATCH UP: OUR CAMPAIGN ON NITRITESHowever, so far they have failed to show any leadership on the issue. In the absence of national action it will be down to inidual councils like the one I lead to make the right decision for our own school pupils.North Ayrshire Council already exceeds the Scottish Governmentrsquos nutritional standards. We have been reducing ham, bacon and cured meats in our school menus by introducing meat-free days. All our Primary Schools have "Gold Food for Le" accreditation. We are sourcing more organic produce and using more local suppliers. However, when The Herald on Sunday asked whether our menu was completely nitrite-free the councilrsquos answer was no.So over the summer our school menus will be reviewed with input from local pupils. Cured products will be off the menu, red processed meats will be reduced and we will be working to source nitrite-free products across the full menu.Guillaume Coudray: removing nitro-meat from schools and hospitals is "urgent"Thatrsquos a decision we will make of our own accord. It reflects our values as a council which has pioneered school holiday meal provision over many years and whose work around dignied access to food has resulted in pound, of funding being awarded in recent weeks to projects led by the North Ayrshire Foodbank and the Three Towns Growers allotment group.The reality, however, is that cash-strapped councils will be left to make their own decisions. The SNPrsquos failure to offer an alternative to Tory austerity and instead dump cuts on to local government means that councils, including SNP-led authorities, are struggling to maintain even basic services. When councils are fighting just to keep teachers in front of pupils is it any wonder that three-quarters are not exceeding national nutritional standards and banning nitrites from school menus This is a national public health issue. It requires national leadership and it needs a government that genuinely works in partnership with councils to make the best decisions for Scotlandrsquos young people, not one that starves councils of resources to a level where cancer-linked chemicals become an acceptable part of school meals.Councillor Joe Cullinane is the Labour leader of North Ayrshire Council

title: scottish-labours-top-candidate-corbyns-brexit-strategy-is-costing-us-votes
story: David Martin said Corbyn, who is sceptical about a second Brexit referendum, is trying to ldquoride two horses at once and complained that his message ldquoisnrsquot cutting through.Askedhis UK leader would be an asset on the doorsteps, the party veteran replied: ldquoIt would be mixed, letrsquos be honest.The Herald on Sunday can also reveal that senior Scottish Labour figures have questioned their partyrsquos campaign strategy of attacking Brexit Party figurehead Nigel Farage.Labour and the Tories are expected to be routed at the European elections this week after MPs failed to come to a resolution on leaving the EU.Tory voters are angry that their party has failed to deliver Brexit, while pro-Remain Labour supporters are furious that Corbyn is not unequivocally backing a second referendum.Corbyn wants to secure a Brexit deal in line with Labour values, or secure a general election. If neither proposition materialises, Labour will back the ldquooption of a public vote.However, Corbynrsquos nuanced position is frustrating Scottish Labour activists, as over % of voters north of the border backed Remain in the EU referendum.Many activists want Scottish Labour to become a voice for staying in the EU and fear that the current position could result in their party losing one or both of their Brussels seats.Martin, who as an MEP since  is Scottish Labourrsquos longest-serving parliamentarian, is top of his partyrsquos list of candidates. He is also a staunch Remainer who believes there should be a confirmatory vote on any Brexit deal.Speaking to the Herald on Sunday, he said of his partyrsquos campaign: ldquoWe are realistic about our prospects. We are not in any way expecting to expand on the two seats we already have. Frankly, our objective is to hold the two seats wersquove got.He said of Labourrsquos layered position on Brexit: ldquoBluntly there is still a bit of confusion about where we stand.Asked whether he believed the message was clunky, he said: ldquoIt is. I wouldnrsquot pretend it is easy to get it across. Sometimes when you are campaigning, it is two minutes on the doorstep and you move on. On this issue, thatrsquos not possible so, bluntly, you do have to spend a bit of time explaining it to people. Itrsquos a complicated message.By contrast, he said the pro-Remain parties, such as the SNP, Lib Dems and Greens, have a ldquovery simple message:ldquoI think there is a need for clarity in our message. A more straightforward message would certainly get a better resonance on the doorstep.Asked whether a pro-Remain policy would be more likely to result in Scottish Labour holding its two seats, he said:ldquoI think it would be, far, far more likely. Our European message isnrsquot cutting through as well as wersquod like it to. So, yes,we had a clearer message we would get more votes.On Corbyn, Martin said there was a contrast ldquobetween the European candidates and the message that is still coming out of the Leaderrsquos office.He added that voters point out the contradiction between his pro-Remain view as a candidate and Corbynrsquos pro-Brexit stance:ldquoIn the context of the Brexit debate, he [Corbyn] does come up as lsquowell, you say that to me, but thatrsquos not what your leader is sayingrsquo. And you get another whole discussion about what the Leader is trying to say.Martin said Corbyn is popular with some younger voters, but warned: ldquoHe has come across as appearing to ride two horses at once.On whether the Brexit policy will cost Scottish Labour votes, he said: ldquoYes. My worry is we are going to underperform in relation to our national standing.However, he said that an intervention tomorrow by former Prime Minister Gordon Brown, who backs a second referendum, will make a ldquobig dference.Asked what his message to Corbyn is, days before voters go to the polls, Martin said: ldquoBe clear that Labourrsquos wants a second referendum.This newspaper also understands that a stormy meeting of Labour MSPs last week led to fierce criticism of the partyrsquos strategy.MSPs are unhappy that Corbynrsquos face, not Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard, is on the partyrsquos election leaflet. They also believe it has been a mistake for Scottish Labour to focus on Farage, as he is not judged to be a front-line politician north of the border.A Scottish Labour spokesperson said: ldquoScottish Labour MEPs will play a pivotal role in tackling tax avoidance, climate change and leading the cause of progressive politics in Europe.

title: high-steaks-the-lowdown-on-the-carbon-emissions-on-our-plates
story: We have taken five dferent dishes, made from ingredients easily available in supermarkets, and crunched the numbers on carbon impact. From these figures its possible to see how local, eating seasonally, swapping some meat for animal proteins and looking at our portion sizes can have an impact. But we also need to urge our government to push for a change in our supply. This is a challenge for all of us ndash government, farmers, retailers, consumers. Itrsquos not just whatrsquos on our personal plates that needs to change, but our national larder.Note: Not all of the greenhouse gas impact of these foods is made by CO. Other gases are included and their added-together impact is expressed here as what the equivalent in CO would be, or as COe.The King Prawn Stir FryFarmed King Prawnsg  kg COeTwo years ago a study revealed the shock news that king prawns were, by its calculations, worse in terms of emissions than beef. What it said was that around kg of COe was produced per kilogram of prawns. That figure was derived by factoring in the fact the aquaculture lagoons in which the prawns were being farmed were created by destroying the mangrove forest. These tropical forests in saltwater are considered a vital storage system of whatrsquos called ldquoblue carbon. Previously such farmed shrimp were found to result in lower greenhouse gas emissions than wild caught prawns ndash as North Atlantic prawn fishing involves extensive trips using up huge amounts of fuel.Joanna Blythman restaurant review: Ostara,  Coburg St, LeithSince then the Vietnamese government has said that they are working to improve the way the country farms prawns, and setting new targets for sustainability ndash though many still continue to farm intensively.For a lower carbon option, replace with Scottish rope-grown mussels with emissions of only g per kilogram.Red pepperg  g COeA  World Wildle Fund report listed that peppers grown in the UK produced around . kg CO emissions. Those grown in warmer parts of Europe release less, at . kg CO.Mangetoutg  g COeor g COe Mangetout sold in UK stores mostly comes from Africa, arriving predominantly by air, though some does make its way by sea freight. Mike Berners Lee lists mangetout as one of a number of vegetables that are likely ldquowhen out of season, to have been air-freighted orgrown in an articially heated greenhouse.Noodlesg  g COeNoodles and pasta are mostly wheat, which causes emissions of around .kg of CO per kilogram in the UK.Cashew nutsg  g of COeJust round .kg of CO released per kilogram of cashews. However labour conditions in the cashew industry are so bad they are sometimes called "blood cashews".Steak, Tatties and VegSirloin steakg   to  kg COeThe chief reason beef has its huge impact is that cows burp methane, a greenhouse gas  times as potent as carbon dioxide. As with most foods, the story around beef isnrsquot simple. One steakrsquos emissions arenrsquot the same as another ndash and the impact ies widely according to how the beef has been farmed, what the cattle are fed on, what breed they are, and whether they are reared on land cleared by deforestation. It has been calculated that beef raised on deforested land is responsible for  times more greenhouse gas emissions than cows on natural pastures. Since Scotland was deforested long ago, this isnrsquot a factor considered with Scottish beef.Herald on Sunday campaign: time to dump nitro meat from schools and hospitals#In Scotland we produce a lot of beef ndash more than we eat. Are the emissions from a nice grass-fed steak, farmed in Scotland, far better than the global average  Andso by how much  This is a debate that rages. One recent study found that grass-fed beef actually has a higher carbon, as well as land-use footprint. However, research from the Rowett Institute in Aberdeen has also found that a substance found in plants in bioerse pasture systems added into the diet of lambs reduced emissions of methane by %.The range among farms is huge. But whatever the iation, it remains that case that beef emits  times more GHG emissions per gram of edible protein than common plant proteins, such as beans.Meanwhile, there is still hope for steak lovers. The notion of breeding or bioengineering low emissions cattle has gained a lot of traction recently. Researchers in Scotland have shown that some cattle have a gut flora that produces less methane, and speculated on the possibility that cattle could now be bred for this. There have even been experiments in putting a small amount of seaweed into cows diet ndash which has resulted in decreased emissions from cow burps.Potatoesg  g of COTatties are low carbon footprint pleasures. According to Mike Berners Lee, author of How Bad Are Bananas kg of boiled potatoes, cooked gently with the lid on produces g of CO. Much of this is produced by the boiling of the potatoes and less than g can be attributed to the growing.Spinachg  g CO equivalent Stilton Cheeseg of Stilton: g COThough our UK consumption of meat has been falling, our appetite for cheese,m also produced by methane-burping ruminants, keeps rising. While itrsquos hard to find a greenhouse gas figure for stilton, calculations do exist for cheddar, of around kg CO equivalent per kilogram.Veggie brunchScrambled eggs eggs  g COeAs animal protein sources go, eggs are about as low as it gets. A dozen eggs produce around .kg of COe. However, again, numerous factors, around the style of farming, transporting and packaging impact on this. Mike Berners Lee observes that a study from Cranfield University suggests that, in terms of climate change, organic eggs are about  per cent worse than those from battery farms. He says, ldquoItrsquos worth remembering that climate change is not he only issue. If you care about animal welfare as well as climate change, buying fewer eggs but making them organic might be a sensible compromise.Breadg  COeUniversity of Manchester researchers looked at sliced loaves and found footprints ranging from  to g CO per loaf. They said, ldquoWholemeal thick-sliced bread packaged in plastic bags has the lowest carbon footprint and white medium-sliced bread in paper bag the highest.AvocadoHalf  g COeWere now so barmy for the avocado itrsquos hardly possible to buy a brunch without a splurge of green. This obsession is having its impact. Mexicorsquos avocado boom has also been blamed for deforestation. A study by Carbon Footprint Ltd found that a small pack of two avocados transported into the UK from Chile had an emissions footprint of .g CO. Factors included were the energy, water, fertiliser and pesticide required to grow them as well as the resources used for packing and the energy used in processing and transporting.Cherry tomatoesg   to g of COeOur beloved cherry tomatoes come with a sting. Those farmed in the UK are mostly grown in greenhouses heated by gas and oil. Overrall Spanish tomatoes rate better. One ten-year-old study found that UK cherry production in stand-alone heated houses created over five times the amount of greenhouse gases as the production and transport of their Spanish equivalent. However, a new generation of high-tech UK greenhouses is becoming more energy efficient. But, without a carbon footprint label on your packet, how can you tell which ones Halloumig  g of COe The UK is the number one export market for Cypriot halloumi cheese, this sheeps cheese the go-to replacement for bacon in a veggie diet. But cheese, of any type, creates high emissions. The fact that it is sheeprsquos cheese actually makes it slightly higher, since sheep produce more methane.Mushroomsg  g of COeFish and chipsEntire meal  . kg COeA WWF report estimated that .kg CO emissions would be produced by a plate of fish and chips ndash "the equivalent of  miles driving in the average UK car." Of that, g was contributed by the cod, just g the potatoes. UK chippies are still predominantly using cod and haddock , but itrsquos possible, in the supermarket to pick up alternative fish, including the Vietnamese pangasius or pollock, which are slightly lower emissions. Bear in mind that most wild fish are in danger of overfishing and that farmed salmon has amongst the highest fish emissions levels.Fruit saladStrawberriesg in season  g CO equivalentWhen Scottish strawberries are in season theres no low emissions treat quite like them. Grown without heating, they come in at g per kg. However, outside the season, you have two choices, neither of them good. The first is to buy strawberries grown under glass in the UK, which emit, on average a massive kg for every kg fruit produced. The other is imported strawberries, most likely flown in, and with air miles related emissions.BananaHalf banana  g CO equivalentMike Berners Lee describes Bananas as ldquoa great food for anyone who cares about their carbon footprint. This, he observes is because they are grown in natural sunlight, need hardly any packaging, and keep well during transport. ldquoAlthough, he writes, ldquooften grown thousands of miles from the end consumer, they are transported by boats .Blueberriesg in season  g COBlueberries are in season in the UK between July and September, so out of that time yoursquore going to have to buy them either hot-housed, or imported.Four tips for going lower carbon. Buy local ndash unless its hot-housed, out-of-season fruit and vegetables.. Buy seasonal.. Campaign for the government to change the food supply by setting up the right subsidy programmes for agriculture and regulating retail. The Good Food Nation bill is currently going through parliament and therersquos still a chance to be heard.. Replace some of your meat and dairy with plant proteins

title: scottish-tory-mp-michael-gove-has-the-vision-and-ideas-to-be-leader
story: Stephen Kerr said Gove, a Scot, had the ldquovision and ldquoideas to become the next Conservative leader, adding that a majority of his colleagues north of the border would feel a ldquonatural pull towards him.With the Tories expecting to be routed at this weekrsquos European election, May will come under pressure to set a timetable for her departure from Downing Street.She intends to bring back her draft Brexit withdrawal agreement to the House of Commons, but there is no sign it will be approved and Tory MPs want her to go quickly.In any ensuing contest, Conservative MPs will whittle down the candidates to a shortlist of two, after which the final decision will be made by party members.An opinion poll published yesterday showed that former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson is the grassroots favourite, while fellow Brexiteer Gove was in third place.The duo worked closely together during the EU referendum campaign, but fell out spectacularly after David Cameron resigned. Gove initially backed Johnson to be leader in , but withdrew support and stood himself.Kerr, the MP for Stirling, told this newspaper: ldquoI believe Michael combines a lot of personal and leadership qualities with a lot of experience.ldquoIf you think about his track record in Government wherever he has gone, he has made something happen. Therersquos no question that when he moves into a Government department, there is an agenda that emerges and he manages to marshal the resources to deliver those policies. Thatrsquos not true of all Ministers.He said Gove, who was born in Edinburgh and brought up in Aberdeen, also cared passionately about Scotlandrsquos place in the UK.ldquoIntuitively, because he is a Scot, he understands the issues surrounding the Union. He also recognises the fact that being a Unionist is not a passive description, it has to be about making the Union work. He gets that.ldquoItrsquos not just a case of upholding the Union, or preserving the Union, he would be about strengthening the Union.He said of his Scottish colleagues: ldquoI do think the majority of my colleagues will feel a natural pull to support Michael, not just because he is a Scot, but because he understands the Union.Kerr said that Gove ldquoupset the hard Brexiteers by not resigning in protest over Mayrsquos deal, but claimed he has broad appeal across the party: ldquoHe can bridge the breadth of the church. He can appeal to people in all parts, apart from those with intractable positions.The MP conceded that the previous clash with Johnson would ldquoundoubtedly be an issue for some Conservatives, but he said:ldquoHe is a unier. He is articulate. He has vision and ideas. He is able to translate those ideas into actual policies. I think he would be a very pragmatic leader.Gove visited Kerrrsquos constituency at the weekend to meet farmers and other industry figures. He also spoke at a meeting of the MPrsquos local party.A YouGov survey for The Times of party members - who will have the final say in the contest - put Johnson on %, while former Brexit secretary Dominic Raab trailed on %.Of the others, Gove and Home Secretary Sajid Javid were on %, with Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt on %.

title: students-buying-a-lottery-ticket-for-education-at-cash-strapped-university-staff-claim
story: University of Abertay chiefs this week told employees that they were looking to cut around  jobs, blaming a lack of funding from the Scottish Government for their decision.The Herald on Sunday understands some departments are set to be decimated by the cuts, with seven out of eight employees in one department and nine of  in another being targeted for redundancy.Sources say students set to join the university next term are now facing an ldquoeducation lottery due to the lack of resources, and claim the impact on lecturers who remain will be ldquounmanageable.They also say rumours have circulated around campus that the institution may be planning to pass over all of its courses except computer gaming ones to Dundee University ndash a claim the institution has denied.A source at Abertay said: ldquoLast year staff predicted when they started cutting the courses that they want to make the computing programmes as successful as possible and then amalgamate everything  with Dundee university.ldquoAlthough nothing has been confirmed, they say they will continue to recruit staff for the computer games programmes while everything  is just being cut. Itrsquos not hard to see whatrsquos going on. The redundancy packages are a joke, and they have left this so late that I donrsquot see how they can fill the lecturing posts they need for next year at this time,they do cut so many people in inidual departments.ldquoStaff are incredibly stressed, disappointed and also concerned for the students who are there now and those coming in the new term.ldquoTheyre not paying for an education, theyre paying for a lottery ticket when they come here ndash who knows what teaching staff will be left or what state the courses will be in by then.ldquoIt is bizarre that the university say that demand for courses is increasing, yet they are cutting staff. It makes no sense.The student president Tam Wilson said the proposals were ldquoextremely disappointing and questioned the timing of the announcement.He said: ldquoWe have no doubt of the impact this will be having on staff at the university and they, along with both staff unions, have our full support at this worrying time. We stand opposed to any redundancies conducted in this way.ldquoNot only will this lead incoming students to question the universityrsquos commitment to their degree, this may adversely affect PHD students with potential changes in supervisors."We believe we are now in danger of moving into a precarious culture at Abertay. With what appears to be large shts within the university taking place on a regular basis, we are aware of staff insecurities from all departments across the university.ldquoWe believe it is no coincidence that this move to redundancies is taking place at this time while lecturing staff are at their busiest, marking student assessments, and the majority of students are off campus after their exams.A spokesman for the university said: ldquoThe university has begun consultation with some staff and the trade unions to ensure that our teaching and research activities can be effectively and sustainably delivered with the right mix of staffing across our academic subjects and services. We hope to achieve reductions in academic staff numbers on a voluntary basis and anticipate around  roles being affected.ldquoThis decision was taken in the context of continued real-terms cuts in Scottish Government funding and signicantly increased costs related to academic staff pensions.ldquoWith demand to study at Abertay increasing year on year, and both student applications and student numbers on the rise, our key priority is to continue to provide the best possible student experience and first-class teaching and learning.ldquoWe will continue to recruit staff in areas where we have identied need and teaching will continue as normal across all programmes.ldquoThere are no plans to merge with the University of Dundee or any other university.

title: customers-took-to-facebook-to-quiz-travel-company-over-future-holidays
story: Stock market analysts Citigroup declared on Friday that the companys shares should be marked at zero and chief executive Peter Fankhauser admitted it had made operational losses of pound.bn in six months.Thomas Cook, the UKs oldest travel firm, is also labouring under the burden of "heavy debts" of around pound. billion.Warning of a bleak outlook for the business, Citi analyst James Ainley said its troubles were likely to unsettle consumers and drive further weakness in bookings.:Thomas Cook shares drop % amid bail-out bidNews of the companys problems has caused panic among some of its customers.On the Thomas Cook Facebook page, one traveller posted: "Im flying to Menorca six weeks today. I hope the financial situation will be settled soon."Another said: "I just booked for next May to Turkey I really hope youre not going into liquidation."A third wrote: "Are you going into administration  Because I have a holiday booked in October."Justin Waite, , from Southampton, who hosts a podcast for private investor community Vox Markets, booked a holiday to Mexico for July with Thomas Cook and is worried about the companys uncertainty.The father-of-two said: "I am a private investor and so I know about balance sheets and at the moment Thomas Cook have liabilities four times the size of the entire company and they are making a loss so they cant reduce this debt."They lost pound.billion in the last six months."Luckily we have insurance but I fear there may be some who dont. I will not book another holiday with them again as I fear they are going to go bust."Im sure Im not the only person thinking this, which will make their business suffer even more."Thomas Cook said that all its holidays are ATOL-protected meaning customers will be able to get a refundit collapses.The company has struggled in recent years to keep up with changing habits of customers.Online aggregator sites, such as Chinese-owned Skyscanner, pose a particular challenge.:Thomas Cook shares nosee on fresh profit warning as Brexit takes its tollRather than booking through a sole agent, many holiday-makers can now use such sites to scan the web for the best offers on flights and hotels.The company, which is valued at poundm and had  million customers last year, put their airline business up for sale in February in a bid to raise some much-needed cash.It has previously blamed Brexit and an uncertain customer environment for its poor financial performance.The company is currently taking drastic money-saving measures to ensure it stays afloat, including axing  head office roles, and closing  stores and  retail jobs.Auditors Ernst  Young this week said there was "material uncertainty" around the sale of the firms airline ision.However, while publishing its half-year results, the auditor said that the company, a British household name, should be able to stay afloat considering all the uncertainties it faces.In a tweet, the firm wrote: "This announcement has no impact on future holidays or flight only bookings."All our holidays are fully ATOL-protected, so customers can continue to book with confidence."Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at trading firm CMC Markets, said: "Thomas Cooks woes have gone from bad to worse after Citigroup downgraded the shares to sell with a p price target. Investors appear to be losing confidence in the ability of management to turn the ailing business around.":easyJet says poundm loss in line with expectationsThe travel firm dates back to , when -year-old Thomas Cook sold a one-day rail excursion for one shilling per head from Leicester to Loughborough.The first trip, inspired by Cooks belief that the working-classs lives could be improved by travel and education, carried  people.The company now sells package holidays, operates airlines in several European countries, owns hotels in  countries and has a travel money and insurance branch.

title: new-lanark-world-heritage-site-how-it-was-almost-lost-forever
story: For generations it provided work, housing and an escape from the desperate poverty and hopelessness that gripped Scotland.But when the cotton looms of New Lanarkrsquos mill eventually fell silent, the th-century buildings which once represented a visionary dream fell into disrepair and began to collapse.And by the early s, the mill and its associated homes ndash a remarkable example of industrial innovation and social reform ndash were tottering on the brink of being lost forever.Today New Lanark founder Robert Owenrsquos vision of a thriving utopian community that combined manufacturing excellence with decent living conditions and education for workersrsquo children, is a Unesco World Heritage Site which attracts , visitors every year.World Whisky Day quiz: test your knowledge about Scotlands national drinkBut as remarkable pictures from a new exhibition show, its towering walls were once dangerously close to crumbling, homes once occupied by scores of grateful families were in disrepair and the entire site was little more than a ghost town.Itrsquos a far cry from the teeming village and mill where  people once lived and worked ndash and a leap from todayrsquos visitor attraction.The exhibition, which is due to open later this year, will tell the story of the village during the era which saw it fade, close and deteriorate.And it includes wishful visions for the sitersquos future drawn up by Glasgow School of Art students, which imagine a mill that s to its roots providing shelter, employment and community for its people.Suggestions for a future New Lanark include a role as a refugee settlement, arts and crafts workshops, inter-generational community projects, mental health rehabilitation and even a vertical "high rise" garden.According to Helen Martin, collections officer at New Lanark, the architecture studentsrsquo ideas combine the millrsquos traditional ethos with a modern era ndash eventhey are simply "wishful thinking".ldquoSome involve large-scale building which obviously we are not going to do. But New Lanark was always supposed to be a living and working village ndash it was never intended as a museum or frozen in time.ldquoSo we need to think about the future and what ways we can use the spaces we have in new ways and keep it alive and relevant.:Island le could be transformed with first of its kind plans to boost economyThe mill and village, in a gorge by the side of the River Clyde, was founded in  by cotton mill entrepreneur David Dale.However, it was his son-in-law Robert Owenrsquos remarkable vision for a form of "industrial utopia" that would see workers live in harmony with the mill, taking advantage of education and with vastly improved working and living conditions, that made New Lanark unique.Owen, disturbed by conditions hersquod witnessed in Britainrsquos mills, resolved to support workers ndash many of whom had come from the poorhouses of Glasgow and Edinburgh or were Hebridean islanders fleeing their failing crofts in search of a better le.Among his welfare programmes was the first infantsrsquo school in Britain, which opened in .The mill and village were celebrated across Europe as a perfect example of industry, engineering and social reform, but by the mid-th century its production methods were outdated and uneconomical.Itrsquos then owner, Gourock Ropeworks, halted production in  but struggled to sell the mill. Homes began to suffer from lack of investment and the model village became outdated, tired and in need of care.Residents drted away, and by  the historic mill and its associated buildings could easily have vanished had it not been for a committed group of people who understood its unique value and set about saving it from crumbling.ldquoThere was a time when the future of the village was really uncertain, said Ms Martin.ldquoThe mill closed in  mainly because it wasnrsquot financially viable. But no one wanted to take on the mill because they would have had to take on the housing and all the upgrades and renovations it needed.ldquoIt would be a large undertaking. So, the buildings were just left to the elements, to the point that it was quite bad.By the time New Lanark Conservation Trust was set up in the mid-Seventies, the top two floors of number one mill, which is now the sitersquos hotel, had collapsed, and walls of other buildings were being shored up by wooden props.Scotlands Insider Guide: ArbroathA turning point came when the buildings were listed for their historical signicance before a compulsory purchase order in  enabled work to begin on saving the structures.Ms Martin said the aim of the exhibition was to look at the industrial heritage of the past, New Lanark now and its future, and to remind visitors how close it came to being lost.ldquoWe wanted to show that the mill hasnrsquot always been as it is now, and there was a time when the future of the villagers here was really uncertain, she added.ldquoThere has been very intensive work done over  years to save the industrial buildings and the houses.One of the sitersquos two main mills is now New Lanark Mill Hotel, while the other draws thousands of visitors every year to see the heritage centre with its working loom and to pay homage at the birthplace of one of the first examples of a planned settlement.The smaller mills are used as office space, with room for exhibitions and events, while New Lanarkrsquos houses are now home for around  people in a mix of private and social housing.

title: game-of-thrones-the-hidden-parallels-to-modern-life
story: As one billion viewers around the planet hold their breath for the final episode of Game of Thrones, superfan Neil Mackay uncovers the hidden messages it has to tell about le in the st centuryIMMIGRATION, climate change, mental health, MeToo, race, religion, public shaming, banking, inequality, disability, the failure of politics, and pacism.These arenrsquot topics yoursquod immediately associate with a TV show best known for sex, violence and dragons, but they lie at the heart of Game of Thrones. The epic series comes to an end on Monday amid a welter of hysteria as viewers finally learn whorsquoll emerge victorious after eight bloodstained seasons telling the story of the battle for the Iron Throne of Westeros.With a global audience of one billion, itrsquos easy to dismiss GoT as simply highly polished massndashmarket TV. But that would seriously underestimate what George RR Martin ndash who wrote the books which inspired the show and and helped create the series ndash has to say about le in the st century.Part of the secret of the showrsquos success is that it taps directly into very modern concerns. A scene might take place in a brothel or involve a sword fight on a lonely road, but more often than not it will be making comment on issues like childrenrsquos rights, infertility, or alcoholism. Itrsquos not a show afraid to take on the big questions facing humanity today.Susan Swarbrick: Why naming children after TV characters is a perilous ideaImmigrationOne of the biggest storylines in GoT sees the leaders of Westeros ndash the fantasy setting for the show ndash trying to keep Wildlings from their land. Wildlings, a sort of mashndashup of Picts and Vikings, live north of Westeros ndash a medieval kingdom like th century England ndash and are kept out by a giant man-made wall. ImagineTrump built Hadrianrsquos Wall.The Wildlings are culturally very dferent to the people of Westeros and so are feared and hated. However, with their land facing destruction, they want to get south and over the wall to safety. They are refugees fleeing war.Unsurprisingly, Lena Headey, who plays evil queen Cersei Maisie Williams, who plays heroine Arya Stark and Liam Cunningham, who plays fan favourite Ser Davos Seaworth, have all spoken out on the need to help Syrian families escaping violence.Mental healthPost-traumatic stress disorder looms large in GoT. This isnrsquot the kind of show where survivorsfrom battle without mental scars. Many characters are profoundly damaged ndash none more so than Arya Stark. The show centres around the enmity between the Starks, and their rivals the Lannisters.Aryarsquos father Ned Stark is executed in front of her when she is just a child. Forced to run for her le, Arya tramps the land in disguise, facing rape and murder at every turn. She channels her fear and anger into revenge becoming a highly accomplished killer by the time she reaches adulthood.But Arya is a psychological wreck. She obsesses on violence, can carry out acts of brutality without batting an eye, and has all but expunged empathy from her emotional palette. She displays all the symptoms of PTSD, including hyper-vigilance and a fragmented sense of identity ndash at one point she even gives up her own name.As Shahida Arabi, the author of books such as The Smart Girls Guide to Self-Care, says: "Arya endures what is known as complex trauma throughout the show ... drastically shaping her personality and worldview."DisabilityItrsquos rare to watch a show with so many disabled characters ndash even rarer to find the characters portrayed in a positive and honest fashion, including the figure many see as the star of the show, Tyrion Lannister played by Peter Dinklage. As Tyrion says, he has been on trial his entire le for being a dwarf. Yet he remains a man of intelligence, charisma and passion.Other characters are paralysed, another has lost a hand, one has a profound learning disability, and another has a facial disfigurement. The show rarely,ever, tips over into sentimentality or paints disabled people as whiter than white ndash theyrsquove flaws, theyrsquore real, and theyrsquore never allowed to forget their disability, and are often cruelly humiliated for it.Disabled activist Rebecca Cokley says until GoT shersquod "never seen my own experience in le reflected so accurately, so vividly, so viscerally".: Game Of Thrones fans hoping for answers as series endsMeTooLe is dreadful for women in Westeros. Women are told when to marry and who to marry women and girls are raped in war women are sold into sexual slavery women are abused within marriage. Yet, as GoT nears its conclusion, itrsquos the women who have emerged as the strongest, most intelligent characters ndash though often driven by all-consuming desire for vengeance after the treatment theyrsquove endured.In a show renowned for killing its stars, the number of men who were front and centre when the show started has been severely reduced in size. Most are dead or no longer in charge. In this final series, women command.Sansa Stark, played by Sophie Turner, has gone from the most victimised character to something akin to Boudica. "Itrsquos funny the way [my storyline] is kind of mirroring whatrsquos happening in real le," says Turner. "How all these women who were subjected to a lot of horror and oppression are taking a stand."The very modern phenomena of public shaming and "slutndashshaming" were also incorporated into GoT ndash most infamously when Queen Cersei was paraded naked through the streets by a mob. Jon Ronson, writer of So Yoursquove Been Publicly Shamed, said the scene was basically Twitter brought to le.Climate"Winter is coming" ndash the three most repeated words in the series. From the opening scenes, viewers have been aware that something is very strange about the seasons in Westeros ndash summers last for years, and when winter finally comes itrsquos a mini Ice Age.The changing climate doesnrsquot just bring disruption and suffering ndash it brings death. As winter comes, so do the White Walkers ndash an army of the undead, risen from the snow, out to destroy humanity.The leaders of Westeros, however, are too busy fighting among themselves to pay attention to the coming winter. The parallels with climate change are one of the few hidden messages which Martin will admit to, saying: "The people in Westeros are fighting their inidual battles over power and status and wealth. And those are so distracting them that theyrsquore ignoring the threat of lsquowinter is comingrsquo, which has the potential to destroy all of them."ReligionReligion is hated in Game of Thrones. Not by the characters ndash most of them are in thrall to one church or another ndash but by the creators. Whenever religion rears its head, misery follows in quick succession.Therersquos a multiplicity of faiths in GoT and all are flawed. Torture, persecution and murder are carried out in the name of religion. Fathers burn their own daughters at the stake. Religious fanatics assault and tyrannise ordinary people. One of the most evil characters in GoT is the priestess Melisandre, the "Red Woman" and follower of the "one true god, the Lord of Light". Her religion is one that favours fire and blood rather than forgiveness and peace.Gods throughout the book are mostly useless ndash they donrsquot grant prayers, their prophecies donrsquot come true. Religious leaders are either lecherous hypocrites or stone-cold fanatics.The swipes at religion have clearly stung. One religious writer, Jana Riess, said: "Martinrsquos commentary on the ineptitude and corruption of a state religion is frankly a bit predictable as a cultural product ... Nothing new to see there.":Game Of Thrones star Sophie Turner says husband Joe Jonas saved her leRace and homophobiaRace is a slippery thing in GoT. On the surface there appears to be little racism. No racial epithets are thrown around, and therersquos no white supremacist ideology on display. But people of colour are mostly at the bottom of the pile.Slavery is endemic across one half of the world, and while most slaves are black, it doesnrsquot appear asrace was the reason for their enslavement. Rather the strong enslave the weak.The only time homophobia rears its head is for political reasons. No-one really cares muchsomeone is gay ndash unless, of course, their sexuality can be used to hurt them. One of the most charismatic characters in the series is the bisexual Oberyn Martell, who lives le by his own rules ndash however, he does have the luxury of being a prince.Diversity in casting has been an issue though. Star Wars actor John Boyega said: "There are no black people on Game of Thrones." Thatrsquos not quite true, but certainly black actors are less prominent than white actors.The character of Daenerys Targaryen ndash one of the main contenders for the Iron Throne, due to the fact that she owns dragons ndash also has been criticised for slipping into White Saviour mode. She does a lot of freeing of black slaves and then being showered with love and awe."The beautul part about the show is that it is reflective of the real world," says Michael Harriot, a GoT fan and writer for the online magazine Roots. "Daenerys is basically the embodiment of white privilege. She is inches away from becoming the most powerful woman in the world simply because someone gave her some dragons at birth."Wealth and inequalityIn Westeros, money is the root of all evil. In war, the Iron Bank of Braavos lends funds to whoever financiers think will win no matter their morality or crimes. Wealth is power and power is wealth. If you can buy your way out of prison, yoursquoll live, andyou canrsquot yoursquoll lose your head.The rich are exploitative, decadent, amoral. Petyr Baelish is perhaps the best example in the show of the hedge fund mind at work. One line sums up his attitude to the world: "Brothels make a much better investment than ships, Irsquove found. Whores rarely sink." Donrsquot come to GoT looking for political correctness, incidentally.Meanwhile, the poor live and die in squalor, in places like "Flea Bottom", surviving on a "bowl of brown". The people are there to exploit, intimidate and terrorise ndash and the rich hold scented hankies under the noses when they have to walk among them.Politics"When you play the game of thrones, you live or die. There is no middle ground." So runs the famous quote which gives the show its title.Like today, compromise in politics is dead in GoT. Politics is not about the greater good, itrsquos about iniduals scrabbling for power over the backs of everyone . Itrsquos a self-serving system, and one which only worsens the lives of the "small folk".Only the elite can play the game ndash and the % have to live with the consequences of decisions taken by morally questionable, rich and stupid leaders. Political paralysis is the order of the day ndash with no ruler equipped to understand the complexities of leadership. Everything is broken in Westeros ndash therersquos not enough money, guards canrsquot police the city, news is faked, therersquos no social mobility, the lives of the poor mean nothing. CNNrsquos John Blake says the show offers "eerie political parallels" to the world we inhabit today.WarFor a series that drips blood, therersquos no more pacist show than GoT. Martin has said that "true horrors derive not from orcs and dark lords but from ourselves".War achieves nothing in GoT. The series opens after the assassination of a Mad King, and looks very possibly asit might end with the enthronement of a Mad Queen ndash Daenerys. Throughout the show, Daenerys has moved from put-upon na to full-blown tyrant. In the last episode, she carried out an act of mass murder so appalling that many fans were outraged that their heroine had turned into the ultimate villain. Thatrsquos kind of the point of GoT ndash everyone is morally grey and war reveals that.The Red Cross even studied the behaviour of key characters and labelled them all war criminals, including Daenerys who has crucied people, burned victims alive, and carried out reprisals on civilians.Military violence in the show often seems inspired by the worst atrocities of the last  years. Cities are burned, child soldiers forced into service, prisoners are mutilated, raped and murdered. And all the while the lives of ordinary people,they are lucky to survive, remain unchanged ndash no king or queen betters their conditions through war.In war therersquos just one certainty ndash and itrsquos expressed in an often quoted phrase from the show: "Valar Morghulis". All men must die.The history which inspired Game of ThronesTHE TV series may speak to modern times, but it draws heavily on the past. The greatest influence is the War of the Roses ndash two rich households locked in a death embrace over who will rule a kingdom.The Dothraki ndash a horde of nomadic horsemen ndash are taken straight from the history of Genghis Khan. Daenerys Targaryen is an updated Cleopatra. Brienne of Tarth is a lt from Joan of Arc.The infamous Red Wedding scene ndash in which one rival family slaughters another over dinner ndash was inspired by two Scottish atrocities: the Massacre of Glencoe and the Black Dinner of  when the teenage Earl of Douglas and his little brother were murdered after supper with the young James II at Edinburgh Castle.The Lannister family have more than a touch of imperial Rome about them ndash from poisoning rivals, to killing their father and sleeping with their siblings, the wealthiest family in Westeros cares only about itself and its desires.In case youve missed itGAME of Thrones ends tomorrow, soyou want to know whatrsquos been happening over the last eight years, herersquos a quick catchndashup.The story begins after the assassination of the Mad King ndash Aerys Targaryen, who butchered and tyrannised his people. The realm has been reunited under the usurper Robert Baratheon ndash backed by his old friend Lord Eddard Stark, and married to Cersei, the eldest daughter of the Lannister clan.Cersei kills King Robert and puts their son, the Caligula-esque Joffrey, on the throne. However, Edd Stark discovers that Joffrey is the product of incest between Cersei and her brother Jaime. For his troubles, Stark gets beheaded ndash and so war beings, with rivals lining up to take the Iron Throne.Meanwhile to the north, the Nightrsquos Watch ndash a rag-tag group of soldiers meant to guard the Wall ndash learn that the Wildlings are coming, intent on entering Westeros to gain safety from an army of the undead pursuing them.Across the narrow sea, the surviving daughter of the Mad King, Daenerys, rises from an exiled "beggar princess" sold into marriage to a Queen with three dragons at her back, ready to take back her kingdom with "fire and blood".Mondayrsquos episode will finally reveal who will sit upon the Iron Throne. The only problem is that after eight seasons of apocalyptic violence therersquos not much left of Westeros to rule.

title: time-for-action-new-cultural-campaign-to-urge-msps-to-understand-impact-of-scotlands-visual-arts-scene
story: The issues facing the art scene are, according to a new submission by SCAN to the Culture Committee of the Parliament, at a critical point ndash it says: ldquoThe strength of the sectorrsquos achievement and ambition, however, is not matched by the support provided it. Wersquore talking about a crisis.The campaign is to urge every MSP in the summer recess to engage with at least one aspect of visual art ndash a gallery, a show, an artist in their constituency, an education project, a painting, sculpture, or other work of art ndash and share their experience on social media.Its aims are to "sharpen minds", and to emphasise the important work artists do outside galleries, shows, and festivals.SCAN, in the campaign, is highlighting through a series of case-studies, how art goes beyond the gallery, the white space or the artistrsquos studio, and benefits whole communities.The campaign, however, comes against a background of rising pressures on the visual arts world, and artists.The current winner of that high-profile prize, Charlotte Prodger, a Glasgow-based artist, last week unveiled her new work at the Scotland+Venice show, an initiative which has been staging an independent show at the Venice Biennale since . In Venice, the main UK Pavilion show is by Cathy Wilkes, another lauded artist based in Glasgow.Artists such as Douglas Gordon, Karla Black, Nathan Coley, Martin Boyce, Martin Creed, Christine Borland, Jacqueline Donachie, Richard Wright, Susan Philipsz, and Duncan Campbell, among many others - often, but not always, connected to Glasgow School of Art - have been part of the generation of artists who have made Scotland, and Glasgow, a key site for the creation of cutting-edge art.However, evidence shows that the working le of many,not most, artists is low paid and precarious: many have to work other jobs to make ends meet ndash meanwhile, publicly-funded galleries that show and support their work are caught in the public sector squeeze on funding, support, and city rent rises.The campaign comes before the anticipated publication of the long-awaited National Cultural Strategy of the Scottish Government, which SCAN, a membership body of  members led by director Clare Harris, hopes can include some real financial muscle as well as warm words about the importance of culture to Scotland.She said: ldquoWe think that actions speak louder than words.ldquoFor the sector to move forward in confidence and enthusiasm, then support, investment and funding must be increased. We feel that itrsquos not about simply giving us money to carry on doing what were doing, but also recognising the massive value and impact that visual arts has in the community. We are a vital ingredient in how people in our cities and the country live: visual art is part and parcel of the Scottish identity, it is part and parcel of well-being and we feel that while the visual arts scene is widely celebrated, we would like to see more concrete funding and investment to give it the support that it needs.She said that the new campaign, which she hopes will result in every MSP noting their encounter with art on social media with a #ArtInAction hashtag, will ldquochallenge decision makers to think dferently about art ndash and to recognise its potential by investing in it.In its new submission to the Culture Committee, SCAN paints a stark and potentially picture of the financial pressures on artists, galleries and organisations.Standstill funding of visual arts bodies, such as galleries, by Creative Scotland, which is operating under its own financial pressures, means that by  there will be a ldquoreal term drop in funding of around %.The paper says: ldquoIf this trend continues with the next round of RFOfunding, there is real concern among our members that they will reach breaking point. Standstill will become collapse.SCAN say diminishing levels of investment and funding at both local and national level have left the arts infrastructure ldquoin a fragile state with artistsrsquo livelihoods precarious."Creative Scotland itself is well aware of the limits of its funds, which come in a grant from the Government and through the unpredictable coffers of the National Lottery.Its acting chief executive, Iain Munro, recently told MSPs of the Culture Committee that its direct funding package of pound million ndash around .% of the Governmentrsquos overall budget ndash is ldquonot in tune with the actual potential here in terms of the creative industries being a growth sector for Scotland.The SCAN paper also says that local authorities have to implement some ldquolong term and strategic thinking, noting recent controversial decisions such as proposed cuts of the funding of Peacock Visual Arts in Aberdeen, and the proposed signicant rent rise for Stills photographic gallery in Edinburgh.Most notably the paper calls for ways to be found to create conditions for fairer income for artists: the average working le for an artist is not attending international shows and festivals, but struggling to find time to create work, and finding spaces to create that work, in between other jobs such as teaching.A survey by SCAN two years ago, for Creative Scotlands Visual Arts Review, found that the average total income of respondents was pound,. This dropped to just under pound, for those who were self-employed, who were mainly artists. South of the border, a recent report by the Arts Council of England found that two thirds of artists earned less than pound in the previous year from their art: only % earned more than pound,.It was notable then when Ms Prodger won the pound, Turner Prize in December, she ruefully noted what she might do with the prize money.She said: ldquoIrsquoll live on it. Irsquoll pay my rent and my studio rent and some bills."The SCAN submission points to other countries efforts to make le easier for artists: in Canada there are a number of tax deductions for self-employed artistsand in Belgium a ldquosmall fees scheme ensures small payments are tax exempt.ldquoEssentially the sector is extremely well-qualied, extremely dedicated, low paid and precariously employed.ldquoThere are a lot of people on short term contracts. The very nature of arts funding is short term ndash you have just got the funding for one round and then you have to start thinking about the next application ndash basic stuff like that.ldquoIt is quite striking: the pressure that everyone is under, from inidual artists to directors of arts organisations, to show impact, to show outcomes, to fill in forms and tick boxes, whilst producing the great work that they do.Ms Harris said many MSPs may be surprised by what they encounter this summer.She said: ldquoI think they will see a stream of work and maybe some people that they didnrsquot really know existed. I think they will have some myths busted.These are things like: we are not a lsquodrain on societyrsquo. We are not rich, we are not lsquotortured artists working away in garretsrsquo.ldquoBut we are sole traders, we are small businesses, we are collegiate, we work together, we are hard-working and provocative, all these things ndash and perhaps some people just donrsquot know this.ldquoI hope it concentrates some minds, and raises awareness of why the cultural strategy is important."Nuno Sacramento, the director of Peacock Visual Arts in Aberdeen, backed the campaign and added: "Its really important that politicians and policymakers from all backgrounds have a better knowledge of how valuable a contribution visual art makes to our communities."Through art, a creative, free and safe space can be opened up for people of all ages, abilities and backgrounds to explore new ideas and ways of communicating. It doesnt sit within one box marked culture, but impacts on our lives in many dferent ways, and plays a positive role in our physical and mental wellbeing."She said: "One question for policy makers is this - what do we value  If we value creativity then that needs to reflected in public policy."Artists work really bloody hard and you need to have an energy, perseverance and total unflinching commitment to what you do. But the truth is that its extremely dficult, at times impossible, to earn a sustainable living from your work. I know many really talented people who struggle and sometimes give up. Its a leaking pipe.ldquoIts one of the most precarious careers I know." Often artists are not acknowledged as workers at all but there is some great work being done in the sector in Scotland to challenge this, from the Scottish Artists Union and organisations such as SCAN.There are still misconceptions about how artists work and live, she said.Ms Ewan added: ldquoWhat we need to do is increase awareness outside the sector here in Scotland of what artists actually do, how they actual work with organisations and communities "I think many people are perplexed by this question, perhaps the old fashioned idea of the artist as a singular solitary genius still pervades public and political consciousness, so connecting artists and organisations to policy makers is the next positive step."Scotlands culture secretary, Fiona Hyslop, is not unaware of the work of artists outside the arts world: this week, in fact, she visited the Delta Studios in Larbert, Falkirk: as well as running classes for adults and children, they take social work referrals, offering a creative outlet to people with physical and mental disabilities.The final publication date for her governments National Cultural Strategy, which has already been the subject of public and arts consultations, is still unknown.It is likely to be seen later this year, but it is unclear whether it will come with its own raft of funding packages or policy changes - what is known is that all wings of the Government, not just the cultural policy areas led by Fiona Hyslop, are involved in its progress.A Scottish Government spokeswoman said: "The Scottish Government is making good progress on the National Culture Strategy."With so much rich and ied feedback from our consultation, we are working carefully to shape the content, with the aim of publishing later this year."Ms Harris said she wants more than just enthusiasm expressed in the Strategy, which was published in draft form last year.She said: ldquoThe Culture Strategy [draft] had a lot of great things in it, but we felt that it didnrsquot really commit to saying lsquowe will put the funding in, it is about celebrating the great impact of culture, and it is about celebrating isnt culture brilliant, but it doesnrsquot say we will do this, we will invest in this.She added: "SCANs position is that we need to look more widely and more strategically about how arts are funded, at the national and the local level."We have an amazing scene. But I think people feel that is not backed up by support coming from those that have the power, and thats government and those that make the budgets and create the budgets."THE ARTS IN SOCIETY: CASE STUDIESThe SCAN campaign wants politicians to take note of cultural projects that have impacts outside the arts world.* The Travelling Gallery was founded in , and has since then brought art and artists to schools and communities in inner cities, suburbs, towns, villages and remote rural areas.Many of these communities are identied with the highest deprivation in the Scottish Index of Multiple Deprivation. I think the arts have the ability to hold up a mirror to people and allow them to see these things.*At the Cherry Road Centre in Bonnyrigg, Midlothian, artists from Artlink Edinburghrsquos Ideas Team  Sensory Workshops provide weekly sensory workshops for people with profound and multiple learning disabilities.Liz Davidson, the manager of the centre, said: "Itrsquos an exploration of human relationships built upon mutual trust and equality. All parties involved are learning and exploring their environment and sensory world, listening and observing together."Artlink has worked for the last  years, within the care system, with artists working in collaboration with people with cognitive disabilities and mental ill health.A report on the project by Dr Susan Levy and Dr Hanna Young of the University of Dundee found that: "The work of Artlink and Cherry Road recognises that meaningful experiences are achieved through slowly building authentic and genuine connections. Working with the artist inspires creative thinking which motivates to create a lsquosafersquo space where all can work together equitably, learning from each other opening themselves, and those they work with, up to new experiences and perspectives."

title: the-joanna-cherry-imbroglio-and-how-we-got-to-here
story: The SNP has long maintained an impressive outward solidarity but this tremor, the shting of the partyrsquos internal tectonic plates, has badly shaken it. The reaction has been extreme with on and off the record briefings and sniping at the Herald on Sunday.Senior SNP source: Joanna Cherry is the Boris of the Yes movementCherry strongly denies the bullying allegations, claiming that she is the victim of ldquopolitically-motivated smears and ldquoback stabbing by rivals within party, quipping sarcastically that even the Tories act more honourably by wielding the kne in public. She even appeared to rebuff an olive branch from Nicola Sturgeon who had described her as a ldquomassive asset to the party, stopping short of a wholehearted endorsement of her innocence.Last Sundayrsquos Herald on Sunday exclusive by Hannah Rodger revealed that former case worker Iona Paton accused her of hypocrisy. ldquoI couldnrsquot stay silent any more when she started saying she was the victim of bullying when she knew she was dealing with all these complaints of bullying against her and [office manager] Fraser [Thompson].Four former staffers in Cherryrsquos constituency office have now made complaints which are being considered by Commons officials. A former election agent has also quit the party over what he claims are personal dferences with the Edinburgh South MP.Kevin McKenna: Dysal SNP Westminster group threatens push for independenceThe abuse Cherry faced came when, at an evidence session of the Commons Joint Committee on Human Rights, she questioned representatives of Twitter and Facebook about the online abuse of female MPs. Following that she was deluged with offensive tweets and threats, one message included a cartoon with a gun with the words ldquoDo it.There was also a message which confirmed Cherryrsquos whereabouts at a specic time and placewhich prompted a police escort.Cherry also made a barely-veiled attack on Sturgeonrsquos leadership, saying, ldquoThe problem we have is that from the moment the first parliamentarian complained against was hung out to dry [a reference to colleague Michelle Thomson ] a signal was given to those with petty motivations thatyou seek to smear an SNP parliamentarian the party wonrsquot get behind them, eventhey are exonerated.She also claimed to be surprised ldquowhen no one from the leadership contacted me to inquire after my wellbeing.There is a simmering row, too, within the SNP over transgender rights. Sturgeon is one of those who believe people should be able to self-declare their sexuality. However Cherry, as part of a -strong group, signed a letter urging the Government not to rush into ldquochanging the definition of male and female. By appearing to pick a side she was also involved in another Twitter storm when she was accused of ldquomisgendering, calling someone a him when they clearly wanted to be a her. The dispute over the reforms to the Gender Recognition Act continues.She also queried the main conclusions of Andrew Wilsonrsquos Growth Commission report, on the currency issue, criticising its ldquosoftly, softly approach, and she also wants an indyref sooner rather than later. She has said that another referendum isnrsquot a sine qua non and that, presumably, Sturgeon, with a parliamentary majority, could simply declare independence.:SNPrsquos Joanna Cherry denies bullying claimsSo on three of the main planks of Sturgeon and the SNP leadership she is at odds. On the timetable and manner of holding an independence referendum, on the currency proposals and on transgender rights.She is also a supporter of Alex Salmond, ldquoliking a series of tweets backing online calls to the former First Minister to replace the present one. She has also endorsed tweets calling for the Scottish Governmentrsquos Permanent Secretary Leslie Evans to resign. Evans was the central figure in the botched inquiry into sexual harassment inquiries against Salmond.It all adds up to continuing stre within the SNP and Cherry is clearly not about to back down.
